newsitem.title: UK: UK's Bottomley rules out BBC privatisation.
newsitem.headline: UK's Bottomley rules out BBC privatisation.

text.p: Britain's ruling Conservative party would not privatise the BBC if it wins re-election, National Heritage Secretary Virginia Bottomley said on Tuesday.
Bottomley told parliament's National Heritage Select Committee that selling off the BBC could jeopardise the standards of broadcasting in Britain.

"To privatise the BBC would seem absolute folly unless there were a host of regulations on offer which are not yet in place," she said. "In broadcasting we need diversity and we have diversity unequalled anywhere in the world."
The ruling Conservatives face an election within 3-1/2 months and trail the opposition Labour Party by between 15 and 25 points in opinion polls.
Bottomley said the government's broadcasting policies were aimed at ensuring "variety, choice and quality".
A memorandum from her department to the select committee highlighted the government's commitment that the BBC should remain Britain's main public service broadcaster.
Bottomley said it was likely the licence fee would remain the BBC's main source of revenue although she welcomed its attempts to branch out into new areas of income.

In December, Bottomley unveiled a five-year formula that will leave the licence fee fractionally lower in real terms at the end of the five years. The fee stands at 89.50 stg for a colour set, rising to 91.50 from April.
The committee was concerned that a flood of new television channels through the advent of digital television would threaten the quality of broadcasting.
Last week, British pay television operator BSkyB said it would press ahead with plans to launch a 200-channel digital satellite service later this year.
The week before, a collection of heavyweight TV companies teamed up to form two new digital terrestrial companies offering about 30 channels initially.
But that is just a drop in the ocean. The Cable Communications Association says digital cable television will offer up to 1,000 channels.
Bottomley said her National Heritage department would be watching the quality issue "like hawks".
She said the BBC's obligations in terms of high-quality public service broadcasting were enshrined in its Charter and overseen by its board of governors.
"I can't conceive of circumstances where the governors would go against those principles," she said.

And programming from Channel Four would also get a boost. The government is expected to discuss later this year reducing the levy C4 pays to independent television companies as part of its funding formula. C4 is a non-profit making corporation with a remit to cater for minority tastes.

But Bottomley conceded that the same levels of quality would not be demanded of new broadcasters on digital channels. "Let them fly first, let them be successful and then additional requirements can be imposed later if necessary," she said.
